In exchange, Enamorus-T can wall Ground-type moves from Great Tusk and Garchomp that threaten the aforementioned Fire-types. If Enamorus-T has not set up, it can be vulnerable to super effective attacks from Pokemon that take Draining Kiss well, like Zapdos and Ogerpon-C. However, entry hazards can wear down many of these Pokemon into KO range of Draining Kiss. Enamorus-T's weakness to Stealth Rock limits its ability to set up, so hazard control from the likes of Corviknight and Great Tusk alleviate this. Finally, Psychic Surge Azelf completely prevents Enamorus-T from using Draining Kiss except on non-grounded foes, which increases the pool of Pokemon that can revenge kill it. Therefore, Enamorus-T likes to have a defensive teammates that can switch into Azelf and the foes that Azelf enables.

Spinblocker.description: Thanks to its typing and good physical bulk, Skeledirge serves as an excellent spinblocker that can wall common spinners such as Iron Treads with Earth Eater and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. It also walls threats like Choice Band Cinderace and Zamazenta-C and, depending on its ability, Garchomp and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Skeledirge can then use Torch Song to set up on passive opponents like Scream Tail and non-Well-Baked Body Blissey or Will-O-Wisp to burn an incoming foe, including switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Alolan Muk. Hex alongside Will-O-Wisp does more damage, but Shadow Ball can be used for more consistent damage. Skeledirge pairs well with hazard setters such as Garchomp and Iron Treads, as it allows them to keep their hazards on the field, and they can in turn handle opposing Well-Baked Body Pokemon. Due to its middling Special Defense, Skeledirge appreciates specially defensive teammates like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra. Additionally, a teammate that covers the type that Skeledirge chooses not to be immune to, such as Quaquaval for Earth Eater variants and Corviknight for Desolate Land variants, helps form a strong defensive core. Dark-types like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao also OHKO Skeledirge with a bit of chip damage, so Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can threaten them are appreciated.

Defensive.description: Defensive Quaquaval uses its good physical bulk and typing to act as a physically defensive pivot, checking dangerous threats like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Hisuian Arcanine. Intimidate allows Quaquaval to weaken foes like Chien-Pao and Cinderace for its teammates, while Fluffy grants better bulk to better check Slither Wing and Roaring Moon. U-turn allows Quaquaval to maintain momentum and allows frailer teammates like Slither Wing and Hydreigon to pivot in safely while Rapid Spin offers role compression by allowing it to remove hazards while having a good matchup against entry hazard setters like Iron Treads and Garchomp. A Relaxed nature and 0 Speed IVs allow it to pivot out as slow as possible. Meloetta is a valuable teammate that can switch in on special threats such as Iron Moth and Zapdos that force Quaquaval out. Physical wallbreakers like Meowscarada and Talonflame have a good type matchup against Quaquaval, hence teammates that can force them out like Zamazenta-C and Regieleki make solid partners.

Specially Defensive.description: Garganacl finds itself as a Stealth Rock setter that fits on balance and stall teams with its ability to force progress through passive damage and maintain entry hazards by annoying popular hazard removal options with Salt Cure. Toxic Debris allows Garganacl to punish weak physical attacks like U-turn from Corviknight and Meloetta, while Earth Eater allows it to check and set up with Iron Defense or Curse on Ground-types like Iron Treads, Landorus-T, and Garchomp, and Water Absorb allows it to check Greninja, Inteleon, and Quaquaval lacking Close Combat. Stealth Rock pairs well with Salt Cure, as Salt Cure heavily chips common hazard removal options like Iron Treads and Corviknight, while Iron Defense and Curse allow Garganacl to act as a bulky cleaner late-game. Protect allows Garganacl to scout the opponent's move, heal with Leftovers, and force more passive damage on foes, while Earthquake and Body Press hit Magic Guard Pokemon like Quaquaval and Heatran that otherwise switch in freely. Garganacl's inability to check common special wallbreakers like Sheer Force Iron Moth and Enamorus-T makes pivots like Regieleki and Slither Wing and physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao great partners; in return, they appreciate Garganacl's ability to maintain Stealth Rock on the field and annoy their checks like Hisuian Goodra and Corviknight with Salt Cure. Garganacl gets rapidly worn down by entry hazards when carrying Leftovers, making physically defensive hazard removal options like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval good partners; these Pokemon also check physical wallbreakers that threaten Garganacl like Galarian Zapdos, while it checks the special wallbreakers that threaten them. The aforementioned Magic Guard Quaquaval checks Garganacl lacking Iron Defense + Body Press and can spin away Garganacl's Stealth Rock; Desolate Land Skeledirge can spinblock Quaquaval effectively, making it a good partner for Garganacl.

Desolate Land.description: Thanks to its great offensive typing, excellent coverage, and high Attack stat, Ceruledge makes for a good wallbreaker in the tier. Close Combat threatens Roaring Moon and Garganacl, while Shadow Sneak is used to pick off faster foes like Gengar and weakened foes like Iron Moth, Barraskewda, and opposing Ceruledge, making up for Ceruledge's mediocre Speed. Ceruledge appreciates being paired with entry hazard setters such as Sandy Shocks, Kommo-o, and Garchomp, which can put opposing Pokemon like Empoleon in range for Ceruledge to OHKO, as well as put opposing fast Pokemon in range for Shadow Sneak to OHKO. Faster foes like Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Azelf can threaten Ceruledge and force it out, so it pairs excellently with teammates like Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Empoleon, which can wall these Pokemon, respectively. In return, Ceruledge can threaten their checks such as Scream Tail for Great Tusk and Heatran for Scream Tail. Pivots such as Manaphy, Meloetta, and Corviknight are also nice partners for Ceruledge, as they can bring it in on Pokemon it checks.

Sword of Ruin.description: Sword of Ruin Ceruledge is a potent wallbreaker, thanks to its excellent coverage hitting almost everything in the tier for neutral damage, a high Attack stat, and Bitter Blade offsetting Life Orb recoil. Shadow Sneak picks off faster foes like Gengar and weakened Iron Moth, Hisuian Electrode, and Barraskewda, while Swords Dance can be used to boost Ceruledge's already high damage, letting it OHKO defensive Kommo-o, physically defensive Garchomp, and Zapdos. Close Combat OHKOes Roaring Moon, Well-Baked Body Kingambit, and Garganacl. Fast Pokemon such as Sandy Shocks, Walking Wake, and Chien-Pao force Ceruledge out, so it pairs excellently with bulky Pokemon that can wall them like RegenVest Roaring Moon, Empoleon, and Quaquaval, respectively; in return, Ceruledge can threaten their checks such as Scream Tail and Heatran. Ceruledge can quicky be worn down by Life Orb and entry hazard chip damage, so it appreciates hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz. Due to Ceruledge's frail defenses and several weaknesses, it often struggles to switch in, so pivots like Corviknight, Zapdos, and Manaphy pair excellently with it, being able to pivot it in on Pokemon it threatens.

Primordial Sea.description: Choice Specs Primordial Sea Kilowattrel is an explosive special attacker that takes advantage of Hurricane's and Thunder's accuracy buff in rain to rain down terror on unprepared while also checking Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Cinderace. Weather Ball is Kilowattrel's best option against Ground-types like Iron Treads and Landorus-T which shrug off its other offensive options while also chipping Desolate Land Heatran and Cinderace. Pivoting partners like Landorus-T and Corviknight pair with Killowattrel to create a potent VoltTurn core, constantly creating momentum to easily bring each other in and deal big damage. Because of its ability to force switches, Kilowattrel appreciates teammates like Garchomp and Scream Tail that can both set entry hazards and mitigate its own frailty by switching in. Additionally, because of its weakness to Stealth Rock and inability to heal itself, hazard removers like Corviknight and Iron Treads are required to prolong its life and maximize the amount of times it can switch in. Finally, RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta both comfortably shrug off Kilowattrel's attacks, so physically offensive teammates like Slither Wing and Chien-Pao can chip or remove them, escalating Kilowattrel's potency as a sweeper.

Tinted Lens.description: Tinted Lens Tinkaton is a solid physical wallbreaker that provides utility while using Tinted Lens to bypass resistances to Gigaton Hammer, turning the tables on defensive Quaquaval and Corviknight, activating teammates like Choice Band Chien-Pao that are hindered by these Pokemon. Metal Coat can be considered as it grants Tinkaton a boosting option for Gigaton Hammer without recoil, granting good odds of OHKOing frailer offensive Pokemon like Ceruledge and Magic Guard Quaquaval after minor chip. Swords Dance allows Tinkaton to more effectively wallbreak, Knock Off is excellent utility that cripples switch-ins like Magic Guard Heatran and Volcanion while annoying switch-ins like Corviknight and Iron Treads, Stealth Rock allows it to act as an offensive entry hazard setter, Protect allows it to gain more Leftovers recovery on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn, and Thunder Wave cripples setup sweepers that may try to capitalize on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn. Tinkaton appreciates slow pivots like Corviknight and Meloetta that can live a hit and pivot in Tinkaton safely. Tinkaton also appreciates faster teammates that make up for its lackluster Speed like Roaring Moon and Hisuian Electrode. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu pair well with Tinkaton, as it forces numerous switches and removes Heavy-Duty Boots.

Palafin.description: Palafin's powerful priority offense and pivoting make it a dangerous threat even with its standard ability. Jet Punch from Palafin-H easily revenge kills dangerous threats like Kilowattrel, Sandy Shocks, and Talonflame, as well as Chien-Pao after minor chip damage. Palafin is heavily hampered by Desolate Land; to take down their users, Zen Headbutt from Palafin-H easily OHKOes Iron Moth and 2HKOes Ceruledge, while Close Combat flings Cinderace into the sun. Pivoting teammates such as Kilowattrel, Meowscarada, and Corviknight not only form dangerous pivoting cores with Palafin, but also position it to both activate Zero to Hero and fire off its powerful Jet Punch. Due to its frequent need to switch and reliance on a recoil move to wallbreak, Palafin requires effective entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Donphan; WishPass Scream Tail is also a great teammate to heal off chip damage. Even with its strong coverage moves, Palafin struggles mightily against opposing Desolate Land, so reliable switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Slither Wing are strongly recommended. Palafin struggles against Dondozo, making teammates that can punish it like Meowscarada and Spikes Garchomp good additions.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Kingambit excels as a mid-game wallbreaker that can boost on passive foes and tear through the opponent's team with its Adaptability-boosted STAB attacks. Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

Physically Defensive.description: Great Tusk is a premier defensive wall thanks to its high physical bulk and access to utility such as Knock Off and Rapid Spin. Ice Spinner threatens Flying-type Pokemon like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Dragonite. Bulk Up is used to boost Great Tusk's offensive and defensive presence, while Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Corviknight and Earth Eater Skeledirge. Regenerator provides reliable recovery and allows Great Tusk to switch back in to take hits from multiple threats, but Fluffy can be used to reduce damage taken from contact move users like Roaring Moon and physical Kommo-o. Alternatively, Toxic Debris can punish users of physical utility moves such as Knock Off and U-turn, forcing entry hazard removers like Corviknight in. Leftovers can be used for small but valuable recovery, while Rocky Helmet can be used to punish contact attackers. Frailer Pokemon that are weak to entry hazards such as Azelf and Weavile appreciate Great Tusk's ability to reliably remove hazards. Great Tusk's abysmal special bulk makes it susceptible to special attackers like Manaphy and Azelf. Therefore, Pokemon like Hisuian Goodra and RegenVest Manaphy can form a defensive core with Great Tusk, being able to switch into those wallbreakers and force them out with utility like Dragon Tail and Knock Off, respectively.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: A solid offensive typing, a high Attack stat, and wide coverage make Great Tusk a potent wallbreaker. Bulk Up is the main source of Great Tusk's power, increasing its tanking capabilities and offensive prowess. Great Tusk's typing and coverage allow it to set up in front of multiple physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Zamazenta-C. Ice Spinner OHKOes Primordial Sea Zapdos after a Bulk Up, OHKOes Dragonite and 2HKOes Landorus-Therian, while Knock Off threatens Skeledirge and Ceruledge if not running Headlong Rush and cripples defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Quaquaval, and Earth Eater Gholdengo looking to switch in. Close Combat threatens Earth Eater Kingambit and Empoleon, as well as Roaring Moon, while Headlong Rush threatens Iron Moth, Skeledirge and Ceruledge. Toxic Debris provides a layer of danger, putting offensive teams on a timer and forcing Poison-type Pokemon to switch in, while Fluffy helps Great Tusk set up Bulk Up more easily with its heightened physical bulk, making it a powerful tank. Great Tusk is a potent wallbreaker and entry hazard remover, so Pokemon that are vulnerable to entry hazards like Ogerpon-H and Weavile benefit from its presence. In return, they threaten common defensive Pokemon that wall Great Tusk, such as Manaphy and Corviknight. Great Tusk has terrible special bulk and appreciates pivoting, so special walls like RegenVest Roaring Moon and the aforementioned Manaphy make for great teammates. Despite Great Tusk's high Attack stat, it still requires entry hazard chip damage to pick up KOes, Stealth Rock to OHKO itemless Zapdos at +1 and Stealth Rock and three layers of Spikes to OHKO Toxapex. Therefore, teammates like Sandy Shocks and Garchomp, which can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes, are appreciated.

Unaware.description: Scream Tail with its good bulk and excellent typing is a great Unaware user that is able to check a variety of threatening physical setup sweepers like Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Kommo-o while also being potential wincon on its own with Calm Mind. Scream Tail also functions as a Wish passer, providing longevity to Pokemon lacking reliable recovery such as Zamazenta-C, Heatran, and Walking Wake. Calm Mind can be used to set up on opposing setup Pokemon like Manaphy and Triage Enamorus-T, while Thunder Wave can be used to cripple incoming switch-ins such as Ceruledge and Heatran. Frail offensive Pokemon such as Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Weavile appreciate Scream Tail being able to take priority moves from Dragonite and Triage Kommo-o. Scream Tail is vulnerable to Ghost-types like Gholdengo, Gengar, and Ceruledge, so defensive checks to them like Manaphy and Mandibuzz are recommended. Scream Tail is also weak to entry hazard damage, so it is essential to pair it with a reliable hazard remover like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, or Great Tusk.

Pixilate.description: Scream Tail leverages Pixilate Boomburst's natural raw power and its decent bulk and Speed tier to act as a niche Stealth Rock setter that threatens some of the tier's best entry hazard removers like Quaquaval, Mandibuzz, and Great Tusk. Protect allows it to receive its own Wishes safely while acting as an option to scout a Choice-locked foe, like Barraskewda, Azelf, or Sandy Shocks. Scream Tail's ability to force out wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Dragonite allows it to find opportunities to set up Stealth Rock; alternatively, Calm Mind allows it to act as a late-game cleaner after its checks like Iron Moth, Unaware Scream Tail, and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra have been heavily worn down or removed. Scream Tail's ability to maintain entry hazards in the face of spinners like the aforementioned Great Tusk and Quaquaval is greatly appreciated by pivots like Azelf and Barraskewda, which can form deadly VoltTurn cores that appreciate entry hazard chip damage on their checks like Corviknight and RegenVest Manaphy. Scream Tail's weakness to revenge killers like Dragonite, Barraskewda, and Choice Specs Azelf means it requires sturdy teammates like Corviknight, Empoleon, and RegenVest Manaphy, which can switch into these threats, live a hit, and pivot out. Scream Tail appreciates spinners that can maintain hazards on the opposing side. Additionally, Scream Tail appreciates wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Sandy Shocks, which can remove Fire- and Steel-types, allowing Scream Tail to clean the opposing team.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Slither Wing serves as a revenge killer that aims to wear down and outlast its checks. Slither Wing possesses a unique combination of a strong STAB First Impression, U-turn, and Close Combat that is further boosted by a recoilless Life Orb with Magic Guard, which also allows it to switch in freely without racking up chip damage from entry hazards. Flare Blitz allows Slither Wing to hit checks like Intimidate Corviknight harder, while Earthquake hits walls like Toxapex and Skeledirge effectively, Will-O-Wisp can cripple checks like Fluffy Quaquaval and help to wear down defensive checks with added chip damage, and Morning Sun allows Slither Wing to remain healthy throughout a game. Specially offensive threats like Hisuian Electrode and Primordial Sea Inteleon pair well with Slither Wing for its ability to pivot and bring them in on physical walls to force them out and wear them down as well as for opportunities to wallbreak; together, they form a deadly VoltTurn core. Fast physical threats like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao also work well in combination Slither Wing to continuously wear down and overwhelm common physical walls like Corviknight, Quaquaval, and Scream Tail. Reliable hazard setters like Garchomp and Heatran are also appreciated to help wear down checks like Corviknight over the game and take advantage of the plethora of switches Slither Wing forces. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and RegenVest Meloetta are recommended to help pivot Slither Wing in to wallbreak and also absorb revenge killing attempts from the likes of Galarian Zapdos and Iron Moth.

Hadron Engine.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and the former can also fire off Terrain-boosted Discharge. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

Ground Immunity.description: Iron Treads is an excellent spinner that is able to switch into common entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with its own Levitate while also being able to use Knock Off on common switch-ins such as Corviknight. Iron Treads can opt to be a hazard setter itself with Stealth Rock, keep up momentum with Volt Switch on targets like Corviknight, or use Heavy Slam as a strong STAB option for Scream Tail and Chien-Pao. Levitate allows Iron Treads to be immune to Spikes while also being able to spin them away, whereas Earth Eater can be used as an alternative for better longevity against hazard setters like Garchomp and Smack Down Landorus-T. Offensive Pokemon that are weak to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Thundurus-T appreciate Iron Treads's ability to keep hazards off the field, as well as being able to pivot them in safely with Volt Switch. Strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit also are good teammates for Iron Treads, as they can more easily break through Corviknight with Knock Off support from Iron Treads. Iron Treads can be overwhelmed by coverage options from hazard setters such as Liquidation Garchomp, so running Wish Scream Tail, which can increase Iron Treads's longevity, or a secondary hazard remover like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also stave off hits, is recommended. Iron Treads is also vulnerable to strong Fighting-type attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing, so it is advised to pair it with a Fighting-resistant teammate such as Scream Tail or Fluffy Zapdos.

Fire Immunity.description: Well-Baked Body Iron Treads is a spinner with a great defensive typing in addition to a Fire immunity and ability to compress several roles such as item and entry hazard removal into one Pokemon. It is notably able to threaten the tier's premier spinblocker in Skeledirge, allowing it to remove hazards freely. If there is already a Stealth Rock user on the team, Iron Treads can instead use Heavy Slam to check Calm Mind Scream Tail and Enamorus-T, Rock Slide to OHKO Talonflame and Volcarona, or Volt Switch to bring in teammates safely. 236 Speed EVs are used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Pixilate Scream Tail and Primordial Sea users like Inteleon, Greninja, and Quaquaval all appreciate Iron Treads switching into their checks in Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Arcanine appreciate Iron Treads removing items from shared switch-ins like Corviknight and Quaquaval. Fighting- and Ground- types like Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Garchomp threaten Iron Treads, so defensive partners like Scream Tail, Quaquaval, and Corviknight are recommended. Iron Treads's Rapid Spin also supports the hazard stacking effort from partners like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Certain Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge can still threaten Iron Treads with their coverage moves, so it appreciates a secondary check to them like Primordial Sea Zapdos.

Sheer Force.description: With high-Base Power moves and decent Special Attack and Speed, Iron Jugulis is a solid wallbreaker that can outspeed and threaten common specially defensive foes, like Garchomp and Garganacl. Iron Jugulis offers a notable niche, as Hurricane + Dark Pulse + Focus Blast can hit every viable Pokemon for neutral damage. Taunt disrupts attempts to heal, set up, or set entry hazards, allowing Iron Jugulis to better handle Pokemon such as Blissey and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis struggles against special walls like Florges and Scream Tail, so physically offensive teammates like Cinderace and Ceruledge are necessary to break through them. Due to its frailty, it enjoys teammates like Slither Wing and Corviknight that can pivot it in, the latter of which can also remove hazards with Defog. Iron Jugulis also appreciates entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, which can enable it to secure KOs that it would typically miss, such as Garganacl.

Desolate Land.description: Iron Moth makes a great offensive pivot in the tier thanks to its high Special Attack, good Speed tier, and ability to utilize Desolate Land excellently with Fiery Dance and Morning Sun. U-turn lets Iron Moth pivot out from Pokemon that threaten it such as Azelf, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite. Toxic can cripple switch-ins such as Meloetta and Manaphy. Discharge threatens Pokemon like Barraskewda, Primordial Sea Manaphy, Well-Baked Body Corviknight, and Mandibuzz. Dazzling Gleam can 2HKO Dragon-types such as Walking Wake, Dragonite, and RegenVest Roaring Moon, and can OHKO Kommo-o and offensive Roaring Moon. Sludge Wave OHKOs Pokemon like Ogerpon-H and Barraskewda, as well as being able to 2HKO Zapdos and Scream Tail. Iron Moth struggles to break through RegenVest Pokemon such as Hisuian Goodra, Meloetta, and Manaphy, so it pairs well with other offensive Pokemon such as Ceruledge, Weavile, and Thundurus, while in return, Iron Moth is able to absorb Toxic Spikes which can be crucial for its teammates. Iron Moth is weak to Knock Off users like Manaphy, which can allow for it to get chipped down by entry hazards, so it appreciates hazard removal from Pokemon such as Great tusk and Corviknight. Iron Moth also appreciates entry hazards from the likes of Garchomp, Heatran, and Empoleon, which wears down the opposing team, letting Iron Moth guarantee an OHKO on Zamazenta-C as well as pick off weakened Manaphy and Hisuian Goodra. Pivots such as Azelf, Zapdos, and Corviknight can pair well with U-turn Iron Moth sets by forming a VoltTurn core, letting Iron Moth pivot in on Pokemon it checks.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Gholdengo is an extremely powerful special wallbreaker that takes advantage of Nasty Plot, Life Orb, and Steel Beam, the latter two without recoil, to overwhelm special walls. Shadow Ball provides excellent neutral coverage, hitting Manaphy, Hisuian Goodra, and Empoleon. Hex is an alternative with Toxic Debris or other status support and bypasses Bulletproof. Recover gives Gholdengo the ability to heal off damage taken while setting up, as well as simply giving it the longevity to attack the opponent's team throughout the battle. Alternatively, Focus Blast hits Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave slows down faster attackers like Iron Moth and Roaring Moon that try to threaten Gholdengo while powering up Hex to break down bulkier Pokemon like Manaphy. Gholdengo's ability to beat down balanced cores with the sheer strength of Steel Beam benefits faster cleaners like Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Azelf and Walking Wake. If Gholdengo runs Thunder Wave, it can also support other offensive Pokemon that appreciate faster attackers getting slowed down, such as Great Tusk, Ceruledge, and Dragonite. However, Gholdengo is vulnerable to faster Dark-types like Chien-Pao and Weavile, so Pokemon that can check them like Corviknight and Quaquaval are appreciated. Corviknight can even safely bring in Gholdengo with its U-turn. Additionally, if Gholdengo is not using Thunder Wave and Hex, RegenVest users like Manaphy and Meloetta completely wall it, so Pokemon that beat them with super effective STAB moves or physical attacks like Desolate Land Ogerpon-H and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Offensive.description: With Nasty Plot, a fantastic offensive and defensive typing, and solid coverage, Gholdengo is a terrifying wallbreaker that threatens to tear apart teams after a single free turn. Hex can be used over Shadow Ball with Thunder Wave or Toxic Debris support, with Life Orb sets 2HKOing badly poisoned RegenVest Manaphy while also threatening Bulletproof Gholdengo. Recover gives Gholdengo significant longevity and multiple opportunities to use Nasty Plot, while Substitute gives it a free turn to set up Nasty Plot or Thunder Wave against foes like Corviknight and Kommo-o and dodges phazing attempts from Dragon Tail users like Hisuian Goodra and Roaring Moon. Focus Blast hits Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave can boost the power of Hex and spread useful paralysis against threats like Manaphy, Roaring Moon, and Ogerpon-C. Leftovers and Colbur Berry both boost its longevity, with the latter letting Gholdengo survive Knock Off from Roaring Moon or +2 Ogerpon-C, while Life Orb boosts Gholdengo's power significantly, granting it feats such as guaranteeing a 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Make It Rain. If running Focus Blast, Beads of Ruin is an option over Adaptability, boosting Focus Blast's power at the cost of revealing Gholdengo's ability and slightly decreasing the power of its STAB moves. Gholdengo can struggle to break through common special walls like Blissey, Bulletproof Empoleon, and RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, so it appreciates powerful offensive teammates like Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Galarian Zapdos that can handle these walls while Gholdengo picks off physical walls like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Kommo-o. Gholdengo appreciates defensive pivots like Corviknight, Manaphy, and Empoleon that can take a hit and bring Gholdengo in against foes it forces out such as Kommo-o, Pixilate Scream Tail, and Galarian Zapdos.

Choice Band.description: Chien-Pao is a fast and hard-hitting attacker able to burst through many weakened teams with little struggle, with its strong Ice- and Dark-type STAB moves and a Choice Band to increase its already good Attack to threaten many popular defensive Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Mandibuzz, and Zapdos. Chien-Pao uses Sacred Sword in order to guarantee an OHKO on Pokemon like Kingambit, Heatran, and Hisuian Goodra, as well as heavily chipping Zamazenta-C. It can also use Lash Out over Crunch, which can 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight after Stealth Rock damage, though getting extra chip on Corviknight can help to guarantee the 2HKO. With Chien-Pao having one of the highest Speed tiers, it's able to pick up OHKOs on many frailer offensive Pokemon like Ogerpon-C and Gengar, it also works excellently as a revenge killer because of Ice Shard and it's its aforementioned high Speed able to take down weakened Pokemon or force out Pokemon like Ceruledge, Zapdos, and Azelf. Offensive Pivots such as Barraskewda and Hisuian Electrode appreciate Chien-Pao's presence, as they like being able to pivot into Chien-Pao to deal with Hisuian Goodra or Corviknight. Chien-Pao is weak to entry hazards, limiting how many times it can come in, so teammates like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Great Tusk can all help with it whilst also taking hits that Chien-Pao can't take and pivoting to get it in safely. Even with help from pivoting, Chien-Pao does have a hard time breaking through common foes such as defensive Corviknight, Unaware Scream Tail, and Quaquaval, which can all switch in on it fairly easily, but the help of teammates like Mixed Garchomp, Magic Guard Heatran, and Hisuian Electrode can help deal with its checks.

Specially Defensive.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

RegenVest Wall.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

Choice Item Attacker.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

Nasty Plot.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Meowscarada and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

RegenVest.description: Roaring Moon is an excellent user of RegenVest with a typing that plays well into the tier's special setup sweepers and pivots like Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and all variants of Zapdos. Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Great Tusk and Corviknight while also threatening a 2HKO on offensive Gholdengo and an OHKO on Gengar and Azelf. U-turn allows Roaring Moon to pivot out on these switch-ins, and Dragon Tail allows Roaring Moon to force out setup sweepers such as Manaphy, which Roaring Moon cannot meaningfully damage, while letting it rack up entry hazard damage. Stone Edge allows Roaring Moon to threaten the plethora of Flying- and Fire-types that the tier has, such as Thundurus, Iron Moth, and Zapdos, while Iron Head allows it to chip Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Diancie that otherwise can switch in freely. 192 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature ensure that Roaring Moon outspeeds Thundurus and Gengar. Roaring Moon appreciates physically defensive walls like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Quaquaval that can remove entry hazards which limit Roaring Moon's walling capabilities, while it checks the special Electric- and Fire-types that threaten them like Hisuian Electrode and Iron Moth in return. Roaring Moon's presence is appreciated by pivots and wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Sword of Ruin Ceruledge due to its ability to switch into revenge killing attempts from the likes of Hisuian Electrode, Sandy Shocks, and Azelf. Roaring Moon deathly fears Dragon- and Fairy-types like Hydreigon, Walking Wake, and Enamorus-T, making Earth Eater Empoleon a notable partner with its ability to pivot into these Pokemon.

Choice Item.description: With high Attack and Speed and a powerful Knock Off, Roaring Moon is a great offensive pivot and wallbreaker, capable of threatening KOs while also generating momentum with U-turn. Knock Off OHKOes other offensive pivots such as Azelf, Barraskewda, and Hisuian Electrode, while also crippling defensive switch-ins like Corviknight and Great Tusk. Earthquake threatens Steel-types like Heatran and Empoleon, Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Diancie, and Stone Edge hits Flying-types like Zapdos and Mandibuzz. Choice Scarf allows Roaring Moon to safely outspeed previously mentioned pivots, increasing its effectiveness as speed control, while Choice Band turns Roaring Moon into more of a wallbreaker, notably 2HKOing Scream Tail with Iron Head and OHKOing Fluffy Zapdos with Stone Edge. Roaring Moon struggles greatly against defensive Great Tusk, Quaquaval, and Kommo-o, which makes specially offensive partners like Azelf and Walking Wake great, as they allow Roaring Moon to potentially sweep late-game after its checks have been heavily chipped down. Other offensive pivots like Barraskewda and Sandy Shocks also like Roaring Moon, as they can form VoltTurn cores and pressure common switch-ins like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and defensive Zapdos. While fast, Roaring Moon is still weak to priority moves from the likes of Weavile, Slither Wing, and Dragonite, which makes defensive partners such as Corviknight and Scream Tail appreciated as well as Azelf thanks to Psychic Surge negating priority. Roaring Moon racks up chip damage from entry hazards easily with U-turn increasing how often it switches in, meaning that Teammates with hazard removal like Corviknight and Great Tusk are also appreciated. Hazard setters like Garchomp and Kommo-o are also helpful, as they help wear down its checks like Corviknight, allowing VoltTurn cores to be more effective.

Walking Wake's excellent Special Attack, good Speed, and nearly unresisted STAB combination allow it to stand out as either a threatening wallbreaker or powerful speed control depending on its choice of item. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Empoleon and RegenVest Manaphy, Scald provides a more reliable STAB option on non-Primordial Sea sets while also threatening a burn on potential switch-ins, while Dragon Pulse provides a more reliable Dragon-type STAB move. Flip Turn is used in order to gain momentum for Walking Wake's teammates while also pivoting out of unfavorable matchups such as against Empoleon and Blissey. Primordial Sea allows Walking Wake to run Weather Ball instead of Hydro Pump, trading power for accuracy while also giving Walking Wake an easier time switching into Fire-types thanks to the Fire-type immunity. Dragon's Maw significantly boosts the power of Walking Wake's Dragon-type attacks, notably allowing it to OHKO RegenVest Manaphy after a Knock Off and one layer of entry hazards, at the cost of not increasing the power of its Water-type attacks and providing no additional defensive benefit. A Choice Specs can be used in order to increase Walking Wake's effectiveness as a wallbreaker, notably allowing non-Primordial Sea sets to 2HKO RegenVest Manaphy and Hisuian Goodra with Draco Meteor after a Knock Off, while a Choice Scarf can be used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO against would-be offensive checks, such as Weavile, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon. Walking Wake appreciates offensive teammates such as Galarian Zapdos, Meowscarada, and Ogerpon-C, which can pressure switch-ins like Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Desolate Land Heatran. Fast teammates such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Azelf also pair well with Walking Wake, as they appreciate the holes it breaks in the opponent's team while forming a VoltTurn core with the momentum they generate, potentially allowing them to sweep late-game. These teammates can also force out Walking Wake's offensive checks, such as Weavile, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon, which can outspeed it and threaten it with an OHKO.

Choice Band.description: With its high Attack stat and variety of Sharpness-boosted moves, Iron Leaves is a decent wallbreaker that can OHKO common metagame threats like Garganacl and Quaquaval. Sacred Sword allows Iron Leaves to hit Grass- and Psychic-resistant foes like Kingambit and Hydreigon, while Wild Charge threatens Flying-types like Talonflame and Corviknight. Iron Leaves struggles with being prediction-reliant and having low physical bulk, especially with its 4x weakness to the extremely prevalent U-turn, which makes wrong predictions very punishing. Therefore, having defensive teammates like Ting-Lu and Corviknight that can repeatedly pivot it in safely are necessary. Due to its lack of recovery and need for repeated switching, Iron Leaves appreciates entry hazard removers like Iron Treads to keep it from getting worn down. Hadron Engine users like Sandy Shocks are also great teammates that power up both Psyblade and Wild Charge with Electric Terrain.

Swords Dance.description: Ogerpon-W's excellent power, great STAB coverage, good Speed tier, and bevy of useful moves make it a potent offensive threat that can overwhelm bulkier teams with Swords Dance. Ivy Cudgel not only boasts obscene power, but also is non-contact and has a high critical hit chance, bypassing Fluffy and Rocky Helmet and often bypassing Intimidate with critical hits. Power Whip is the preferred secondary STAB move to OHKO Manaphy, while Horn Leech provides recovery. Knock Off hits Desolate Land Ceruledge, Iron Moth, and Heatran, while Play Rough dispatches of Kommo-o, Trailblaze allows Ogerpon-W to potentially sweep offensive teams, and Spikes reliably wears down switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra, (comma) which can get 2HKOed after Spikes. Primordial Sea is the preferred ability to make Ivy Cudgel even stronger and provide a useful Fire immunity, while Sword of Ruin also boosts Ogerpon-W's other coverage, achieving important benchmarks like OHKOing Kommo-o. Ogerpon-W appreciates fast cleaners that can take advantage of the holes it creates in opposing teams, especially fast special pivots like Azelf and Hisuian Electrode that can get it in on special walls and overwhelm the physical walls like Kommo-o that it struggles with. Ogerpon-W has mediocre bulk, so it appreciates defensive teammates like Meloetta, defensive Zapdos, and Intimidate Corviknight to take hits and get it in safely or dual screens support from Prankster Corviknight to let it set up safely.

Ogerpon-H is a strong wallbreaker that is able to beat many of the tier's premier walls, such as Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Great Tusk thanks to its high Attack, excellent STAB moves, and good Speed tier. Power Whip can be used to get massive damage on Ground- and Water-types, including securing the KO on Intimidate Quaquaval and physically defensive Great Tusk after Swords Dance, while Horn Leech can be run instead to give Ogerpon-H more longevity. Ogerpon-H has a number of options for its last moveslot, such as Play Rough to hit Kommo-o and Roaring Moon, OHKOing both after a Swords Dance, and Knock Off to cripple foes, especially switch-ins like Primordial Sea Zapdos, which gets 2HKOed after Stealth Rock, as well as 2HKOing Well-Baked Body Gholdengo with Sword of Ruin. Desolate Land provides the most power to Ivy Cudgel and lets Ogerpon-H offensively check Water-types like Manaphy and Barraskewda, while Sword of Ruin allows Play Rough to OHKO Kommo-o and 2HKO Garchomp. Due to its average defenses and lack of recovery if not running Horn Leech, Ogerpon-H benefits both from entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Quaquaval and slow pivots like Corviknight and Empoleon that can get it on the field safely. Ogerpon-H also appreciates hazard setters like Garchomp and Heatran, which can chip down walls like Scream Tail for it to more easily KO.
